experiment_info.base_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Hey, thanks for meeting with me. Honestly, I'm just feeling a bit overwhelmed with everything right now and I'm not sure where to even start.

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 10/10 (Very outgoing)
- Agreeableness: 1/10 (More competitive)
- Conscientiousness: 6/10 (Moderately organized)
- Neuroticism: 8/10 (Very sensitive to stress)
- Openness: 7/10 (Very creative and curious)

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 3/10 (Low)
- Communication style: Passive
- Triggers: Networking events, Presentations, Campus social events
- Social comfort: 4/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Computer Science
- Fears: Choosing the right career path, Social anxiety in large lecture halls, Academic failure and poor grades, Dealing with roommate conflicts
- Goals: Improve public speaking, Get accepted to graduate school, Publish a paper, Learn a new language
- Challenges: Financial planning, Finding a mentor, Managing student loans
- Behaviors: Eats at the dining hall, Participates in study groups, Volunteers for campus events

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hey, no worries—it's totally normal to feel that way! Since you're low on social anxiety, start by using that strength: reach out to professors or upperclassmen in CS for mentorship—they can help with grad school advice and career direction. For finances, check if your university offers free financial planning workshops. And for public speaking, maybe join a club like Toastmasters to practice in a supportive setting. You've got this—just tackle one thing at a time!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I could email a couple professors, but I'm worried they'll think I'm just another student trying to get ahead. And Toastmasters sounds... like a lot of pressure, honestly.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a fair concern, but professors expect these emails and many genuinely want to help! Keep it brief—mention a specific topic from their work you admire. As for Toastmasters, it's designed to be a supportive space for beginners. Maybe just observe a meeting first to ease in. You're capable of taking these small steps!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I could try emailing Professor Davies about her human-computer interaction paper... but Toastmasters still sounds intense even just observing.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a great first step—Professor Davies will appreciate you mentioning her specific work! For Toastmasters, how about starting with something smaller? Your university might have a low-key public speaking group or class. Even practicing in front of a few friends can build confidence. Every bit helps!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I could ask around about smaller groups, but even the thought of practicing in front of friends makes me feel judged.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Totally get that—it's vulnerable! Maybe start by recording yourself talking about a topic you love, just to get comfortable hearing your own voice. It’s private, zero-pressure, and builds confidence for when you’re ready to share with others. You’ve got this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I could try that with one of my coding projects... though hearing my own voice back still makes me cringe a little.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Haha, everyone feels that way at first—it's totally normal! The cringe factor fades quickly, I promise. Think of it like debugging code: you're just identifying small areas to improve, not judging your whole self. Keep it short and focused on your project. You're building a really useful skill.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess... it's just hard to believe the cringe ever fades when you're the one in the spotlight. I'll try to keep it focused on the project, though.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly—focus on the project, not yourself. The "cringe" fades because you'll start noticing your progress more than your voice. Think of it as leveling up a skill, just like mastering a new programming language. You're already on the right track by being willing to try.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, that makes sense when you put it like leveling up a skill. I just really hope this project is good enough to get noticed for grad school applications.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: For sure—and a well-explained project can really make your application stand out. Grad schools love seeing you articulate your process clearly. You're not just showing code; you're showing you can communicate complex ideas. That's a huge plus!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, I just worry my project isn't as impressive as everyone else's. I get stuck trying to explain why the algorithm I chose matters.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a common hurdle! Instead of comparing, focus on your unique reasoning. Why did *you* pick that algorithm? What problem does it solve better than others? That personal insight is what makes your project—and your explanation—genuinely compelling. You've got this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess that makes sense... it's just hard to remember my own reasoning when everyone else seems so much more confident in theirs.

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Hi, thanks for meeting with me. I'm really nervous about this, but I know I need to get better at talking to people.

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 2/10 (Introverted)
- Agreeableness: 9/10 (Very cooperative)
- Conscientiousness: 8/10 (Very organized)
- Neuroticism: 4/10 (Moderately sensitive)
- Openness: 1/10 (More traditional)

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 9/10 (Severe)
- Communication style: Direct
- Triggers: Office hours, Group projects, Job interviews, Presentations
- Social comfort: 2/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Computer Science
- Fears: Finding a job after graduation, Living away from family for the first time, Time management with coursework
- Goals: Develop leadership skills, Build a strong professional network
- Challenges: Career exploration, Dealing with academic pressure, Navigating campus politics, Building time management
- Behaviors: Joins student clubs and organizations, Procrastinates on assignments, Calls family frequently, Studies in the library regularly, Stays up late studying

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hi! I totally get feeling nervous—I’m the same way. It’s brave of you to take this step. Start small: maybe chat with one classmate after a lecture or join a low-pressure online study group. People are often friendlier than we expect. You’ve got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay. I'll try the online study group first. I'm just worried I won't know what to say.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a great first step! Try preparing a couple questions about the coursework beforehand—it gives you an easy way to jump in. Remember, everyone's there to learn, so you're already on common ground. You'll do better than you think!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay. I'll write down two questions before class. I'm just worried my voice will shake when I ask them.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's totally normal! I still get shaky sometimes. Try taking a deep breath before you speak—it really helps calm nerves. People are usually focused on the content, not how it's said. You're doing great by preparing!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I know you're right, but my mind just goes blank the second I have to speak in class. I'm worried this will happen in a job interview.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a common fear! Practice really helps—try recording yourself answering questions, or role-play with a friend. Interviews often have predictable questions, so preparing answers in advance can reduce that blank feeling. You're building skills now that will help later!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I've tried recording myself, but hearing my own voice just makes me more anxious. What if I prepare answers and still blank out when they're actually looking at me?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a smart concern. Instead of memorizing, try writing bullet points for your answers. This gives you flexibility if you blank. In an interview, it's okay to pause and say, "Let me gather my thoughts"—it shows you're thoughtful, not unprepared. You've got this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay. I'll try the bullet points. I'm just worried my mind will still go completely blank when they ask about my leadership experience.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a great start! For leadership, think of one small example—like helping a classmate understand code. You don't need a big story. Practice saying it out loud once a day. It'll feel more natural over time. You're capable of this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay. I'll try that. But what if I explain it wrong and they get more confused?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a valid worry! Keep it simple. Use the STAR method: Situation, Task, Action, Result. Briefly state what happened, what you did, and the outcome. Practicing this structure will make you feel more in control. You can do this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay. I'll try the STAR method. But what if I blank out during the interview and can't remember the structure?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's totally normal! Write "STAR" at the top of your notepad as a quiet reminder. If you blank, take a slow breath—it's okay to say, "Let me think for a moment." Interviewers expect a little pause. You've prepared well; trust yourself.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay. I'll write STAR. I'm just worried I'll freeze up when they ask why I'd be a good fit.
